author: Andrea Mandell
title: PricewaterhouseCoopers 'deeply' regrets major Oscars flub
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email PricewaterhouseCoopers 'deeply' regrets major Oscars flub Warren Beatty was 'given the wrong envelope,' the accounting firm says. Post to Facebook PricewaterhouseCoopers 'deeply' regrets major Oscars flub Warren Beatty was 'given the wrong envelope,' the accounting firm says. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2muVHNE Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs PricewaterhouseCoopers 'deeply' regrets major Oscars flub Andrea Mandell , USA TODAY 5:05 a.m. ET Feb. 27, 2017 Warren Beatty explains to the audience how he had the wrong award card for best picture during the 89th Academy Awards at Dolby Theatre. (Photo: Robert Deutsch-USA TODAY NETWORK) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The show is not over. 
When the Oscars ended on Sunday night with the biggest flub in recent memory, thanks to Warren Beatty mistakenly reading La La Land out as the winner of best picture, when, in fact, the prize went to Moonlight , the night ended with an uproar â€” and more questions than answers. 
That's why just after midnight, PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm that tallies the Oscars, released an apologetic statement. 
"We sincerely apologize to Moonlight, La La Land , Warren Beatty, Faye Dunaway, and Oscar viewers for the error that was made during the award announcement for Best Picture," the statement read. "The presenters had mistakenly been given the wrong category envelope and when discovered, was immediately corrected. We are currently investigating how this could have happened, and deeply regret that this occurred." 
Read more: Here's how the worst flub in Oscar history went down 
The accounting firm's statement concluded: "We appreciate the grace with which the nominees, the Academy, ABC, and Jimmy Kimmel handled the situation." 
How "immediately" was the flub corrected? La La Land producers may debate that come Monday morning, given the time allotted for them to take the microphone to express their gratitude after the mistaken win. 
"I would not wish that situation on my worst enemy," David Oyelowo told USA TODAY at the Governors Ball. "That was a tough way to find that you lost and a tough way to find out that you won." 
Relive how it all went down here . Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Faye Dunaway and Warren Beatty walk on stage to present the best picture award at the 89th annual Oscars. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Warren Beatty is holding the envelope for Actress in a Leading Role, not Best Picture. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Beatty hands the envelope to Dunaway who says 'La La Land' is the best picture winner. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY The cast and crew of 'La La Land' celebrate after the film was mistakenly named best picture during the 89th Academy Awards. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Jordan Horowitz, a producer for 'La La Land,' holds up the card showing 'Moonlight' as the real best picture winner. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Warren Beatty speaks to Brian Cullinan, a CPA from PriceWaterhouseCoopers after the mix-up. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Warren Beatty explains to the audience that he had the wrong award card for best picture. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Barry Jenkins accepts the award for best picture for 'Moonlight.' Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Warren Beatty exits the stage after announcing the award for best picture at the Oscars.
